events.long_description:
After what must be their 10,000th voyage to their favourite touring destination (give or take a few), Ben Ottewell and Ian Ball, founding members of the legendary Gomez, return to Australia and New Zealand for another run of unforgettable, up-close-and-personal shows.
This time, it’s by request.
Calling all fans, Tijuana Lady’s, actually Me, You, Everybody to See The World through the eyes of Ian Ball and Ben Ottewell as they Bring Their Lovin’ Back Here to New Zealand.
Expect the best tunes from the best of 25 years of touring to Australia and the best albums Bring It On, Liquid Skin, and beyond all delivered with Ben Ottewell’s unmistakable growl and Ian Ball’s melodic brilliance.
No rules. Just two mates, two guitars, some electronic stuff, and decades of songs that have soundtracked road trips, breakups, breakdowns and breakthroughs.
It’ll be intimate and loose, but it’s your chance to hear the songs you love, the way you’ve never heard them before. By request.
Make sure you fill out the song request form here: bit.ly/GomezByRequest

events.id: Roxy Retro | Danger: Diabolik-5 Park Rd, Miramar, Wellington 6022, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Roxy Retro | Danger: Diabolik
events.venue: 5 Park Rd, Miramar, Wellington 6022, New Zealand
events.long_description:
The suave, psychedelic-era thief called Diabolik can't get enough of life's good - or glittery - things. Not when there are currency shipments to steal from under the noses of snooty government officials and priceless jewels to lift from the boudoirs of the superrich. The elusive scoundrel finds plenty of ways to live up to his name in this tongue-in-cheek, live-action caper inspired by Europe's popular Diabolik comics. He clambers up walls, zaps a press conference with Exhilaration Gas, smacks a confession out of a crimelord while freefalling with him from an airplane, and pulls off the heist of a twenty-ton gold ingot. Impossible? No, diabolical - Danger: Diabolik, to be exact!
Presented in 4K

events.id: SAYA GRAY + Karen Nyame KG + MĀ-92 Vivian St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: SAYA GRAY + Karen Nyame KG + MĀ
events.venue: 92 Vivian St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Drunken Piano, Banished Music and The Others Way festival are hyped to announce a huge debut NZ appearance on Friday 28th November 2025 for Canada’s Saya Gray at Wellington’s stunning Meow Nui. Support comes from UK producer DJ Karen Nyame KG and Te Whanganui-a-Tara local artist Mā.
Taking the stage in Wellington ahead of her Others Way Festival appearance the next night, Saya Gray will be performing material from her excellent record released earlier this year SAYA.
Saya Gray has earned a reputation for electric, hypnotic live performances, leaping between instruments and genres, beguiling and entrancing her audiences.
“The alt-pop experimentalist delivered a mesmerizing, emotional performance with a triumphant sense of self” – Range Magazine
Watch her NPR Tiny Desk performance here.
Sharing the Meow Nui stage with Saya is UK DJ, producer, vocalist Karen Nyame KG.
“Channeling a deeply rooted attachment to the African diaspora, KG’s innovative and percussive assemblage of dance music spanned amapiano, afrobeats, uk funky, gqom and beyond.” – Resident Advisor
You can check our her boiler room set at Primavera here.
Rounding out the evening is local artist Mā. With their second album “Blame It On The Weather” being released earlier this year, Mā told RNZ “I’d rather talk about how we can move forward, how we can evolve, how we can work together better”.
Don’t miss this celebratory evening of creative expression and artistic genius. With Saya Gray and KG performing for the first time in New Zealand, tickets are on sale now from ticketek.co.nz

events.id: Sharon Van Etten & The Attachment Theory-The Opera House, 111 - 113 Manners Street, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Sharon Van Etten & The Attachment Theory
events.venue: The Opera House, 111 - 113 Manners Street, Wellington
events.long_description:
BANISHED MUSIC & STRANGE NEWS PRESENT
SHARON VAN ETTEN & THE ATTACHMENT THEORY

TUESDAY 25 NOVEMBER - THE OPERA HOUSE, WELLINGTON*
THURSDAY 27 NOVEMBER - ISAAC THEATRE ROYAL, CHRISTCHURCH*
SATURDAY 29 NOVEMBER - THE OTHERS WAY FESTIVAL, AUCKLAND

* with special guest SHANNON LAY (USA)

Banished Presale: 11AM, Thursday, June 19th
Subscribe for Banished pre-sale at www.banishedmusic.com/subscribe

General On Sale: 11AM, Monday, June 23
Tickets from Banished Music

“...right up there with Van Etten’s most majestic tracks ever” - www.consequence.net

“A new dawn for the music of the night.” – The Times

“...you could be forgiven for thinking that this latest incarnation of Sharon Van Etten has seen her reborn.” – The Herald (Glasgow)

Following the gigantic recent announcement that Sharon Van Etten & The Attachment Theory are headlining The Others Way Festival this November, Banished Music and Strange News are delighted to reveal the band are also set to play their very own shows in Wellington and Christchurch, with very special international guest Shannon Lay joining in support at both shows.

Hot on the (six-inch patent black stiletto) heels of their self-titled album, Tuesday 25 November will see Sharon returning to Wellington’s Opera House with her remarkable new band in tow, and playing Christchurch’s Isaac Theatre Royal on Thursday 27 November, before heading up to slay The Other’s Way’s very first outdoor Karangahape Road stage.

That her band’s debut album is her own seventh album is a testament to Van Etten’s willingness to reinvent and follow her instincts for change, even after this long on the job. Now sixteen years into an extraordinary career, it seems our heroine has fully accepted her mantle as one of the world’s great rock stars, fronting her gothic-tinged new outfit to widespread awe and acclaim, Devra Hoff on bass guitar and backing vocals, Teeny Lieberson on keys, guitar, and backing vocals, and Jorge Balbi on drums.

“The Attachment Theory are a tight unit, woven together by Devra Hoff’s inventive, intelligent bass lines... this show was less about [Sharon’s] past and more about her future, which appears to lie with The Attachment Theory - a band who, on this evidence, are bringing the very best out of her.” – Manchester Evening News

Also performing at The Others Way, and playing support in Wellington and Christchurch, American songwriter Shannon Lay is much of a punk as she is a folk singer, citing both The Ramones and Nick Drake as influences. As a member of garage rocker Ty Segall’s Freedom Band, Lay can certainly make a racket, but for these shows, she will be opening as a solo act. The Guardian were quick to assure us that “This is no mere indie-folk musician,” and Pitchfork said her most recent studio album “presents a quiet, lovely, undramatic rendering of the dramatic”.

We truly could not be more excited to be welcoming Queen Shazza back to Aotearoa for these shows, and with the addition of both her band The Attachment Theory and Shannon Lay’s opening spot, you should be dang well excited too!

“Sharon Van Etten and The Attachment Theory’s self-titled record is an early Album of the Year contender” - www.independent.co.uk

events.id: Roxy Retro | Monty Python and the Holy Grail-5 Park Rd, Miramar, Wellington 6022, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Roxy Retro | Monty Python and the Holy Grail
events.venue: 5 Park Rd, Miramar, Wellington 6022, New Zealand
events.long_description:
50th Anniversary
A comedic send-up of the grim circumstances of the Middle Ages as told through the story of King Arthur and framed by a modern-day murder investigation. When the mythical king of the Britons leads his knights on a quest for the Holy Grail, they face a wide array of horrors, including a persistent Black Knight, a three-headed giant, a cadre of shrubbery-challenged knights, the perilous Castle Anthrax, a killer rabbit, a house of virgins, and a handful of rude Frenchmen.

events.id: Astronomy On Tap-Space Place at Carter Observatory, 40 Salamanca Rd, Kelburn, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Astronomy On Tap
events.venue: Space Place at Carter Observatory, 40 Salamanca Rd, Kelburn, Wellington
events.long_description:
Experience the wonders of the Universe as you embark on an extraordinary journey into the vast depths of space and beyond.

All stars are born, they live, and they die; and out of the dust, more stars are born. Join us as we uncover the stories hidden in beautiful clouds of stellar nurseries, growing giants, and dying cores, learning about the life cycle of stars and the cosmic forces that shape our night sky.

Upon arrival, enjoy a drink and your first-class inflight snacks before settling into our digital full-dome planetarium for a guided tour through the galaxy. Complete your stellar adventure with visiting our interactive exhibitions and stopping at the cash bar.

Whether you’re accompanied by a special someone, a friend, or embarking on a solo adventure, raise your glass to the stars and enjoy the ride.

$45pp | Last Tuesday of every month | 8PM – 10PM | R18 | Space Place

events.id: High Dependency Unit with Special Guest W.I.T.C.H - Wellington-92 Vivian St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: High Dependency Unit with Special Guest W.I.T.C.H - Wellington
events.venue: 92 Vivian St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
After close to a decade away from live stages, the mighty High Dependency Unit return this November announcing their first shows since 2016 including a key festival performance at The Others Way, and an all ages show in Port Chalmers to kick off the tour.
Since their formation in 1993, HDU have carved out a singular space in Aotearoa’s music landscape, fusing and funneling shoegaze and psychedelic noise into hypnotic, sonic power. Their live shows are the stuff of legend, their studio output of essential albums and EPs through the 90s and 2000s have become touchstones for generations of musicians both here and abroad.
The return of Tristan Dingemans, Neil Phillips, and Constantine Karlis to the stage and a rare chance to witness HDU in full flight is nothing short of a seismic event. These November dates will see the band revisit their formidable back catalogue and remind audiences why they’ve long been considered one of New Zealand’s most powerful live acts.
Adding to the magic of the incoming High Dependency Unit NZ tour, HDU’s Wellington Meow Nui show will feature very special guests W.I.T.C.H. on the bill. The legendary 1970s Zamrock pioneers whose psychedelic rock, funk, and African rhythms have made them cult icons around the world, W.I.T.C.H. (We Intend To Cause Havoc) are in the midst of a global renaissance, bringing their irresistible live energy to new generations making this one-off pairing with HDU an utterly unmissable night.

Banished Music pre-sale - Friday 29 August, 10AM
General on sale - Monday 1 September, 10AM
Tickets & Info from Banished Music
Subscribe to presale at banishedmusic.com/subscribe

events.id: Little Blast Trio with Oscar Laven-272 Taranaki Street, Wellington-Facebook
events.name: Little Blast Trio with Oscar Laven
events.venue: 272 Taranaki Street, Wellington
events.long_description:
Little Blast Trio (with special guest, Oscar Laven), play the music of ‘Triplicate’ - the 1988 album released by the Dave Holland trio on the legendary ECM label.
“Holy shit! You can do that in jazz?” thought these young players upon encountering it almost 30 years ago. Sure can! It’s time to put this lovely mix of tunes through their paces, refracted through the prism of these four stalwarts of the craft who have performed extensively in Aotearoa and beyond over the last few decades. Should be quite a gig.
Little Blast Trio is:
- Blair Latham ~ Tenor Sax/Bass Clarinet
- Alistair Isdale ~ Acoustic Bass
- Darren Mathieson ~ Drum kit
- with Oscar Laven ~ Tenor Sax/Bassoon
$15 presale tickets via UTR
$20 door sales ($10 unwaged)
Special thanks to CNZ for supporting Pyramid Club's programme

events.id: The Red Shoes (1948) screening - Powell and Pressburger-10 Kent Ter, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: The Red Shoes (1948) screening - Powell and Pressburger
events.venue: 10 Kent Ter, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
This is a screening for Wellington Film Society members only - to join grab a three-film sampler member ($40) or a full year membership ($120). https://wellingtonfilms.nz/join/
This film is playing twice - first at 6pm on Monday 24 November and then again at 8.30pm on Tuesday 25 November.
“The Red Shoes plays in my heart” – so says legendary director and cinephile Martin Scorsese, who personally assisted and championed the 4k restoration of the 1948 Powell and Pressburger epic which concludes our theme “Dancing on the edge” and closes out our 2025 programme.
Real life ballerina Moira Shearer stars as Vicky Page, a ballerina who rises to stardom under the watchful eye of svengali Boris Lermatov. Vicky is cast in Lermatov’s new production, “The Ballet of the Red Shoes”, based on the Hans Christian Andersen fairytale of the same name. In the prevailing gender norms of the 1940s, Vicky must choose between her career and her marriage – but will the mysterious power of the red shoes mean they have the final say?
The Red Shoes revels in its glorious Technicolor aesthetic, and for Scorsese offers the perfect synthesis between colour, sound, editing and cinematography. Nowhere in the film is this more evident than in the legendary 17-minute ballet sequence, which uses all aspects of filmcraft to weave between the action and Vicky’s psychological state. The influence of this sequence is clear in films like Hitchcock’s Vertigo (1958).
events.description:
This is a screening for Wellington Film Society members only - to join grab a three-film sampler member ($40) or a full year membership ($120).
https://wellingtonfilms.nz/join/ This film is playing twice - first at 6pm on Monday 24 November and then again at 8.30pm on Tuesday 25 November.
“The Red Shoes plays in my heart” – so says legendary director and cinephile Martin Scorsese, who personally assisted and championed the 4k restoration of the 1948 Powell and Pressburger epic which concludes our theme “Dancing on the edge” and closes out our 2025 programme.
Real life ballerina Moira Shearer stars as Vicky Page, a ballerina who rises to stardom under the watchful eye of svengali Boris Lermatov.
Vicky is cast in Lermatov’s new production, “The Ballet of the Red Shoes”, based on the Hans Christian Andersen fairytale of the same name.

events.id: Pixies-St James Theatre, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Pixies
events.venue: St James Theatre, Wellington, New Zealand
events.description:
They influenced the sound of the 90s.
American alt-rock band Pixies formed in 1986.
Still popular more than 35 years later, they are heading to the St James Theatre for a two-night residency.
On the first night, they’ll play two 90s classic albums in their entirety – ‘Bossanova’ and ‘Trompe Le Monde’.
For the second night, they’ll play from their new album ‘The Night The Zombies Came’ plus other songs from their catalogue.

events.id: Pixies - 2025 New Zealand Tour-St James Theatre, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: Pixies - 2025 New Zealand Tour
events.venue: St James Theatre, Wellington
events.description:
PIXIES have announced a 2025 New Zealand tour which will see the alt-rock legends perform two consecutive nights in both Auckland and Wellington.
On the first night, they’ll play classic albums, 1990’s Bossanova and 1991 follow up Trompe Le Monde in their entirety, followed by a cross catalogue set and songs from their new album The Night The Zombies Came on the second night.
Pixies have just released their tenth studio album The Night the Zombies Came to critical acclaim, with MOJO saying, This most thrillingly deathly of bands remains alive and DIY stating, Pixies remain one of the most consistent, influential bands on the planet.
Pixies wowed UK fans in August with their mainstage performance at London’s All Points East, described as “raucous” by Rolling Stone UK after their sold-out Glasgow Academy show was tipped as “a full-on head rush of classics by the Scottish Sun and as relevant in 2024 as they were over 35 years ago by Glasgow World.
35 years since their groundbreaking Platinum-certified album Doolittle catapulted the band into the UK Top Ten, and 20 years since their celebrated reformation at Coachella, Pixies are deep into their second act, and in the midst of a creative purple patch.

events.id: Dianne Halliday, Organ-St Andrews on the Terrace, 30 The Terrace, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Dianne Halliday, Organ
events.venue: St Andrews on the Terrace, 30 The Terrace, Wellington
events.long_description:
Programme includes works by Carlotta Ferrari, Svitlana Ostrova, Jennifer Bate, Christina Harmon and Fanny Hensel Mendelssohn.


Dianne G Halliday has been active in the organ and church music scene in Wellington since her arrival in 1983. From 1984 - 96 she was Director of Music at the Metropolitan Cathedral of the Sacred Heart, establishing junior and adult choirs and bringing to fruition the expansion of the 1905 Hobday instrument to facilitate its use in contemporary Catholic liturgical practice. During this period she also succeeded in the Fellowship examinations for the American Guild of Organists. In 1997 she began a twenty-three year commitment to St Peter’s Church, Willis Street. Her activities there included the 150 the anniversary of the founding of the parish and continuing the annual Advent Lessons and Carols services. In 2014 she began DMA studies at the New Zealand School of Music at Victoria University, studying with Douglas Mews through 2018. In addition to the Wellington Organists’ Association, of which she is currently president, she has been active in the Royal School of Church Music, of which she was awarded an Associateship in 2023. She formally retired from St Peter’s in 2020 and is now active as a substitute organist and recitalist.

events.name: Art Classes - Term 4 - Creative Kid's Art Lab - 2025
events.venue: Art Lab, 6 Rainbow Court, Raumati
events.long_description:
Art classes & after-school care for children who like to make, create and invent. Located in Raumati, Paraparaumu - Kapiti.

For ages 5-13 on Tues, Wed and Thurs. The kid's art classes are from 3.30 - 5.15pm, however children can arrive from 3pm onwards.


- Qualified primary teacher and artist
- 15 years' experience teaching art to primary-aged children
- Progressive teaching methods
- Lessons based on traditional and modern arts/crafts, developing skills & creativity
- Structured, but in a home-studio setting
- Daily or weekly themes
- A child-friendly, relaxed environment for after-school
- Lots of variety / choice
- Excellent resources

The classes provide an opportunity to play and experiment in a structured but caring, home-studio environment.

Activities are designed and supervised by an experienced primary school teacher and artist.

To meet the needs of active and curious children after school we explore a variety of crafts such as sewing, crochet, pottery, felting, weaving, jewellery and woodwork; and the art forms: painting, drawing, sculpting and printmaking.

The activities utilise a child's growing mathematical skills such as estimating, measuring, scaling up & down, changing 2D to 3D, exploring symmetry, and pattern-making. Natural sciences, such as chemistry, biology, geology and physics are included, as well as history and culture.

See the creativekids artlab website. Phone Helen with any questions.

events.name: Boost Your Business: Finance Foundations - PART 2
events.venue: The Dowse Art Museum and Dowse Square,45 Laings Road, Lower Hutt, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Boost Your Business: Finance Foundations - PART 2
Finance Foundations: Build, Fund & Future-Proof Your Business

About this Event

Come and join us this November in Lower Hutt for our Boost Your Business workshop series, Finance Foundations: Build, Fund & Future-Proof Your Business.

Whether you joined us last time or are coming along for the first time, this free, hands-on series is designed to help you feel confident and in control of your business (or future business) finances. Knowing what options are available to you as a business owner can make all the difference.

Part 2 with Sammie Price, Partnership Manager at HNRY
Sammie’s bringing the real talk on being a sole trader versus running a company. This one’s for anyone wanting clarity and confidence around tax, finance, and those “what am I actually meant to be doing?” questions that come with self-employment.
She’ll myth-bust common misconceptions, walk you through HNRY’s simple tools, and show you how to take the stress out of managing your finances, so you can focus on doing what you love.

If you’re a sole trader (or thinking about becoming one), this is the session you don’t want to miss! Get all your HNRY questions answered and walk away feeling more in control of your business journey.

Event Details:
Dates: 26 November 2025
Time: Doors open at 5:30 PM | Workshops run 6:00 – 7:30 PM
Catering: Dinner will be served at 6 PM by the amazing team at Amilagi’s Island Cuisine — so come hungry!
to sign up for part 1 of Finance Foundations on 12 November

Spaces are limited, so book your spot today!
You don’t need to be a Pasifika business owner to attend, everyone is welcome. Bring a friend and sign them up too!

events.id: FLINT Wellington: Get to know a CxO-level 6/44 Bowen Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: FLINT Wellington: Get to know a CxO
events.venue: level 6/44 Bowen Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Ever wondered what it really takes to make it to the top? Join us for an evening of speed networking with some of Wellington’s most inspiring executives.
At Get to Know a CxO, you’ll have the chance to move around the room and chat one-on-one with a range of senior leaders. Expect candid conversations about their career journeys, lessons learned, and the moments that shaped their leadership.
This isn’t your typical panel event. It’s relaxed, interactive, and designed to help you connect directly with the people behind the titles. Whether you’re curious about leadership, thinking about your next move, or just love hearing great career stories, this event’s for you.
Come for the insights, stay for the connections ✨
📅 Wednesday 26 November, 5:30 PM
📍 Venue: KPMG - Level 6, 44 Bowen Street, Wellington
🎙️ Speakers: 
Anna Darling, GM People Experience at Sharesies
Phillip Whitmore, Partner - Digital at KPMG
Anna Mitchell, Executive General Manager, Frontier at Chorus
More to be announced!
Spots are limited, with FLINT members taking priority over non-members so register now to secure your spot!
We look forward to seeing you there.
_______________________
About FLINT
If you’re in the early stages of your career and you’re interested in digital technologies, come join the FLINT programme in your local city. We host events, webinars, podcasts and social catch ups that offer valuable networking, learning and growth opportunities. 
Find out more about the Wellington FLINT team here.
  Anna Mitchell, Executive General Manager, Frontier at Chorus
Anna is Executive General Manager, Frontier at Chorus, with accountabilities for fibre footprint growth, copper exit, property optimisation, and corporate affairs, as well as championing Chorus’ sustainability and digital equity ambitions. She brings broad expertise in telecommunications policy and leading strategic initiatives, with experience across both public and private sectors, including roles at Deloitte, SweeneyVesty, and as a senior advisor to a cabinet minister.
  Philip Whitmore, Partner, Cyber and Digital at KPMG
Philip is a Partner within KPMG Cyber with over 30 years’ experience across a broad range of cyber security disciplines. He has worked extensively in New Zealand, as well as throughout the wider Asia Pacific region.  His cyber security knowledge and experience is supported by his wider business consulting background, giving him the ability to readily translate cyber security risks into a business context. Philip’s experience saw him win the New Zealand Cyber Security Person of the Year award in 2023.
  Anna Darling, GM People Experience at Sharesies
Anna is an experienced HR leader with 15 years’ experience across the public and private sectors in New Zealand and the UK. Passionate about human-centred design, she focuses on creating meaningful employee experiences and driving diversity, equity, and inclusion. Anna is especially committed to increasing Māori and Pasifika representation in tech and expanding opportunities for underrepresented groups, drawing on her background in developing women’s rugby and promoting gender equity in sport in Aotearoa. She also serves on the Board of Nuku Ora and was part of the Sharesies team recognised as the Overall 2025 Best Place to Work in October.

events.id: Te Tipu Pakihi Māori Award Dinner-2 Taranaki Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Te Tipu Pakihi Māori Award Dinner
events.venue: 2 Taranaki Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
"Whakatupu: Igniting Māori Enterprise, Innovation, and Growth in Te Ūpoko o te Ika "
Tipu Pakihi 2025 Dinner is here to highlight Māori business growth, foster innovation, and strengthen collaboration across Te Ūpoko o te Ika. Grounded in Māori values and whanaungatanga, this event brings together Māori entrepreneurs, rangatahi, iwi leaders, innovators, business networks, and support agencies to shape a thriving regional Māori economy.
Expect a delicious dinner, awards for successful Māori entrepreneurs, extended networking opportunities, and outstanding entertainment. From rangatahi start-ups to iwi investment strategies, Tipu Pakihi is a space where ideas are nurtured, partnerships are formed, and solutions are co-designed for Māori-led economic development.
This is more than just dinner. It’s a celebration of our people, our creativity, and our future. Come ready to eat, connect, and be moved. The vibes will be high, the kaupapa strong, and the memories lasting.
Whether you're starting out, scaling up, or supporting Māori enterprise, Tipu Pakihi 2025 offers connection, inspiration, and actionable insights.

events.id: Gaza Surf Club - Wellington film screening-93 Mornington Road, Brooklyn, Wellington 6021, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Gaza Surf Club - Wellington film screening
events.venue: 93 Mornington Road, Brooklyn, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
events.long_description:
🌊 Gaza Surf Club - Film Screening & Fundraiser 🌊
Join us for a community screening at Vogelmorn (Upstairs) Wednesday Nov 26th at 7.30pm.
Gaza Surf Club offers insight into the lives of the Palestinian surfing community and their connection to the sea, as well as the ongoing struggles of living under a military occupation. 
Tickets are koha / pay what you can style and will go directly to supporting Sabah Abu Ghanem (a surfer featured in the film) and her family.
What to know for the screening
This is a relaxed event for all those (surfing community or not) who would like to support Sabah and raise awareness about the challenges of attempting to surf under Israeli military occupation in Gaza. 
The venue won't be operating its restaurant during the screening so you are encouraged to BYO snacks or dinner if you wish.
Unfortunately the venue is not wheelchair accessible.
About Sabah
Sabah has been surfing since she was a little girl and has been featured in several documentaries (including Gaza Surf Club). She was taught by her father, Rajab Abu Ghanem who is a renowned fisherman and surfer in Gaza. It was Sabah's dream to start the first girls swim and surf club in Gaza.
Now 26, Sabah has three children and her focus is on the survival of her family.
Here is a link to a recent article she is featured in if you want to follow her journey:
https://www.nytimes.com/2025/10/19/world/middleeast/gaza-city-israel-hamas-cease-fire.html
For more information on Gaza Surf Club, or to support other members of the Gaza surfing community, follow @surfersforpalestine and check out the Gaza Surf Club website.
If you have any questions, reach out to me (Adriana Bird) via instagram @adriana_bird
Hope to see you on Wednesday 26th Nov!

events.name: Ladies FUN Charity Golf Day Pōneke
events.venue: 1 Stewart Duff Drive, 6022, NZ,1 Stewart Duff Dr, Rongotai, Wellington 6022, New Zealand, Wellington
events.long_description:
Ladies FUN Charity Golf Day Pōneke
Come join us for a fun gals day out of golf supporting Wāhine Wanawana - Ara Ki Angitu charitable trust for Women's financial literacy.

This event is a fun ladies day out. Girl golf rules apply! No experience necessary. We ran this event in Christchurch in 2024 and most had never played and had the best time. Great to meet new people and/or network. When you purchase your ticket there will be a place to let us know if you would like to be in a team with a friend.

The details:
Please arrive approx. 20 mins before tee off so we can allocate teams and give everyone a brief.
9 holes, ambrose format, teams will be allocated on the day.
Included:
-Green fees and any club/trundler hire needed
-Balls/tees
-On course snacks and drinks
-After round nibbles
-Prizes
After round drinks can be purchased in the clubhourse at own cost. Golf carts can be purchased with $10 going to the charity.
Nadine (Wahine golfer) will join a lucky team!
All proceeds will go to our charity that runs events to improve financial literacy for women. Holes are available to sponsor at $500 per hole - email if you would like to sponsor a hole or donate prizes.

events.name: Cultivating a Positive Workplace Culture for High-Performance Teams
events.venue: Level 13 157 Lambton Quay Wellington, 6011
events.long_description:
This course is designed for leaders, managers, and organisational change agents who want to foster a positive workplace culture that drives high performance, collaboration, and employee wellbeing. Participants will explore the essential principles of creating an environment that nurtures trust, accountability, inclusivity, and engagement. Through practical strategies, case studies, and interactive discussions, participants will learn how to develop a culture that motivates teams to excel, encourages open communication, and supports professional growth.

Key Topics Include:
• Building a culture of trust and psychological safety
• Fostering open communication and feedback loops
• Aligning values and purpose with organisational goals
• Promoting inclusivity, diversity, and belonging
• Recognising and celebrating achievements
• Encouraging work-life balance and wellbeing
• Developing strategies for conflict resolution and collaboration
By the end of the course, participants will have the tools and insights needed to create a workplace environment that not only supports but accelerates the success of high-performing teams, driving both individual and collective achievement.

Key audience:
This course is designed for leaders, managers, and anyone responsible for shaping the culture within their teams and organisations.

Learning outcomes:
Implement strategies to cultivate trust, psychological safety, and high performance within their teams.
Lead teams that foster open communication, collaboration, and inclusivity.
Align team goals with organisational values and objectives, ensuring a shared sense of purpose.
Develop effective strategies for conflict resolution and team cohesion.
Create a workplace culture that encourages growth, well-being, and work-life balance.

If you would like to register with Business Central directly and receive an invoice for payment, please contact our training team via training@businesscentral.org.nz.

events.id: Voices from the Moana: Amplifying Pacific stories of healing and resilience-42 Wainui Road, Waiwhetu, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Voices from the Moana: Amplifying Pacific stories of healing and resilience
events.venue: 42 Wainui Road, Waiwhetu, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Talanoa Tai Learning is a new collection of learning experiences. They're designed to help you build your cultural responsiveness and improve your ability to engage meaningfully with Pacific communities. Talanoa is a Paciﬁc style of deep dialogue, with a focus on how we connect to each other and strengthen relationships, while still being able to share honest and eﬀective insights. Tai refers to ocean waters, which represent your opportunity to rise through the ebb and ﬂow of this learning journey. If you want to strengthen your capability in this space, to create transformational change, and to enhance your relationships with people from diﬀerent communities - this workshop is your chance to grow.
What will I gain from Voices from the Moana?
In Voices from the Moana, you will explore and share rich narratives of healing and resilience from different Pacific nations and perspectives. The Pacific ocean is a diverse place and we have our own unique stories of healing through traditional practices, beliefs and methods. This Talanoa Tai learning experience invites reflection on your own understanding of different healing modalities from the Pacific and the impact it has on your worldview. It will equip you to advocate for social justice through Pacific voices. You'll gain practical tolls and insights that you can apply directly to your work.
This is a 3 hour in-person learning experience.
Who is this workshop for?
These learning experiences are for both Paciﬁc professionals and those from other communities. You don’t need to have prior knowledge or experience in this area - we’ll meet you where you are and provide a welcoming, supportive environment for you to learn.
Cultural responsiveness is for everyone. Whether you’re in social work, education, government, community sectors or beyond, these learning experiences have been designed to help everyone build their skills. If you think this professional development might be right for you, it is!
Cost
When work is busy and budgets are tight, cultural responsiveness can often take a backseat. But this is an aﬀordable investment that will help you address the challenges that so many of us share, like how to build engagement and trust, and avoid relationship missteps. It’s not a buzzword; it’s a vital skill if you want to better meet the needs of the people you serve. Price: $170 (inc GST) per person, including morning tea.
 Facilitator
Our team’s extensive research and experience feed into these sessions, with a focus on interactive activities and practical, real-life examples. Our team has decades of experience across a range of ﬁelds, in particular social development, education, and research. We have worked with organisations and businesses across the Paciﬁc, and our engagement with diﬀerent Paciﬁc languages, cultures, and communities means we oﬀer robust, informed perspectives. Fa’aeafale’upolu (Polu) Samuelu is the facilitator of this Talanoa Tai Learning experience.

events.id: Karanga taonga, karanga tangata, karanga whenua |Reversing Cultural Amnesia: Activating Māori Practice in Museums-55 Cable Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Karanga taonga, karanga tangata, karanga whenua |Reversing Cultural Amnesia: Activating Māori Practice in Museums
events.venue: 55 Cable Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
In 1947, Māori leader, politician, and scholar Apirana Ngata spoke to his scholarly peers at the Polynesian Society, announcing his greatest desire to revive Māori culture as a living force within communities, not be relegated to dead exhibits in museums (Ramsden 1948, 85).
This lecture acknowledges the concerns of visionary leaders and champions of cultural practice and their activation within museums. Through her work as a Māori curator, writer, cultural practitioner and post-doctoral researcher, Awhina Tamarapa advocates for cultural restoration as a form of liberation in a museum context. In her research, Tamarapa is exploring strategies for the recovery and reclamation of taonga puoro (singing treasures) and karetao (animated storytellers) for new generations.
There are challenges regarding taonga held by overseas museums. Concepts such as keeping taonga warm, and mana taonga, recognises the connection and authority of descendants to their taonga, that underpin this work.
The focus on the reclamation of Indigenous practice has been bolstered by working with First Nations, Canada BC. Led by Professor Bryony Onciul, University of Exeter, UK, Tamarapa was privileged to be part of a research project “The Future of Indigenous Rights and Responsibilities: Ancestral governance, environmental stewardship, language revival, and cultural vibrancy” funded by the Arts and Humanities Research Council, UK.
_________
The Michael Volkerling Lecture series is a partnership event with the Museum and Heritage Studies programme at Te Herenga Waka | Victoria University of Wellington, National Services Te Paerangi and Te Papa Tongarewa. This annual public lecture series recognises the legacy of the late Dr Michael Volkerling who was one of the principal architects of New Zealand's cultural and creative sectors.

There are challenges regarding taonga held by overseas museums.

events.id: Welly Biotech ‘n’ Beers: Speaker Series - November 2025-7 Dixon Street, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Welly Biotech ‘n’ Beers: Speaker Series - November 2025
events.venue: 7 Dixon Street, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
BioTech N Beers presents the third instalment of its speaker series, and the last BioTech N Beers of the year!  
 Once a quarter we will be running a fireside chat with those that have been there done that, the up and coming and everything in-between.
For our final meeting of the year, we are also working in collaboration with Women in HealthTech.
 Women in HealthTech:
Women in HealthTech is a collaborative group representing the HealthTech sector in New Zealand, providing a foundation of networks and leadership.
We have come together to empower women with a diverse range of thinking at all levels of the HealthTech industry and assist with effecting cultural change. Our steering committee represent companies across New Zealand from early stage start-ups and research medical technology companies, to privately owned New Zealand suppliers and global multinationals.
 Kindly hosted by Creative HQ our speaker will be Ipshita Mandal-Johnson telling us about her journey between building a bio revolution to revolutionising bio.
Generously sponsored by FB Rice, come along for a yarn, some war stories, and drinks and kai.
Check out Ipshita’s bio below and we hope to see you there!
 Ipshita’s Bio:
Ipshita has over 15 years' experience in academia, private and public sectors in bio sciences, technology and financial services.
She had completed a BTech in Biotechnology at the University of Auckland (co-funded by Douglas Pharmaceuticals) and a PhD in Chemical Engineering and Biotechnology at the University of Cambridge. She co-founded the Global Biotech Revolution in 2012, led the first GapSummit and growth of GBR activities including events in Singapore and the US till 2017 and is currently still a Steering Committee member. She also worked in a synthetic biology and chemistry biotech Nanna Therapeutics as CBO, which was eventually acquired by Astellas Pharmaceuticals for its rare disease pre-clinical assets. She then worked at McKinsey and Company in the India and US offices primarily in the technology, public sector and pharma practice areas (including as Chief of Staff to a $60Bn merger between Takeda and Shire). She has been an advocate for gender lens impact investing and women’s health through Global Bio Fund (invested in Baymatob in 2022 a med tech in maternal health) and the Xcellerator community.
She has provided advice to a portfolio of innovative and systemic investment projects in NZ through BioPacific Partners, Impact Lab, Malaghan Institute of Medical Research, MBIE funded RNA Development Platform and Advanced Technologies team. She is also passionate about bio systems thinking-philosophy and nature poetry. She has received multiple professional awards including thrice being listed in the UK 50 Movers and Shakers in Bio Business, selected to be a Leader of Tomorrow at the 43rd St Gallen Symposium and twice nominated as a Young Global Leader to the World Economic Forum (2024-25).
 FB Rice:
FB Rice is a leading independent intellectual property firm with a strong focus on biotechnology and the life sciences. With more than 75 years of experience and a dedicated Wellington office, we’re proud to support New Zealand’s growing biotech community through local presence and expertise.
Our Biotechnology Group brings deep scientific and industry knowledge across areas such as gene therapy, diagnostics, biologics, vaccines, and medical technologies. We work closely with clients across academia, research, and industry to protect innovation and support commercial success—offering strategic advice on patentability, prosecution, due diligence, and portfolio management.
As active participants in New Zealand’s innovation ecosystem, we value collaboration and are committed to helping the local biotech sector thrive.
 Creative HQ:
Creative HQ is a global innovation hub, based in New Zealand, that provides programmes for entrepreneurship and public sector innovation. Creative HQ creates change for governments and startups through innovation training, structured acceleration programmes and bespoke support.
Creative HQ, Wellington’s innovation hub, operates throughout New Zealand and internationally across the Asia-Pacific region with significant work experience in the Philippines, Singapore, Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Japan, Hong Kong, India and Australia. They look to build confidence, capability and connectedness throughout their ecosystem while looking to inspire and support the growth of individuals and businesses through the use of design thinking methodologies. This enables the delivery of innovative solutions to their customers.
 Event Details:
Date: Thursday, 27 November, 2025
Location: Creative HQ, 7 Dixon Street, Wellington 6011
Time: 4:30 pm – 6:30 pm
Cost: Free

events.id: Optimising value through methodology - A PMO Case Study: Insights from NZ PMO of the Year 2025-Microsoft, Level 13 , 10 Brandon Street.-Humanitix
events.name: Optimising value through methodology - A PMO Case Study: Insights from NZ PMO of the Year 2025
events.venue: Microsoft, Level 13 , 10 Brandon Street.
events.long_description:
Note: This is a Hybrid Event:
In-Person Location: Microsoft, Level 13, 10 Brandon Street, Wellington.
Online: The Zoom link will be sent out the day before the event.
Networking will start at 5.00pm for the in person attendees followed by the presentation starting at 5.30 pm for both in person and online attendees
About this event:
“The New Zealand Traveller Declaration, that international visitors use today, is the product of over 200 dedicated team members working with focus, collaboration, and resilience over two and a half years through much adversity. It is a privilege to present insights from my experience as PMO lead in this remarkable programme team.”

Join Chris Fisher from Nonsuch as he shares personal insights into the award-winning New Zealand Traveller Declaration (NZTD) Programme, recognised as New Zealand PMO of the Year 2025 (and New Zealand Technical Project of the Year 2025)

Chris will reflect on his experience in the NZTD Programme that overcame complex national challenges to deliver a secure, user-centric digital border solution. He’ll unpack how the PMO supported the evolving nature of the programme and tailored methodologies in a hybrid model, blending agile, traditional, and benefits-led approaches to enable rapid delivery, strong governance, and measurable impact.

Chris will also highlight the practical application of frameworks that help power success, including the PMO Value Ring, and share what made the programme stand out in its PMI award application. Expect practical takeaways, lessons learned, and winning strategies that could help your programme, project, or PMO to drive value.

Whether you're leading a transformation programme or evolving your PMO, this session offers valuable insights into how integrated methodology can unlock real-world results.
About the Presenter:
Presenter: Chris Fisher – Head of Consulting, Nonsuch
Join Chris Fisher from Nonsuch as he shares personal insights into the award-winning New Zealand Traveller Declaration (NZTD) Programme, recognised as New Zealand PMO of the Year 2025 (and New Zealand Technical Project of the Year 2025)

Note: This is a Hybrid Event: In-Person Location: Microsoft, Level 13, 10 Brandon Street, Wellington.
Online: The Zoom link will be sent out the day before the event.
Networking will start at 5.00pm for the in person attendees followed by the presentation starting at 5.30 pm for both in person and online attendees About this event: “The New Zealand Traveller Declaration, that international visitors use today, is the product of over 200 dedicated team members working with focus, collaboration, and resilience over two and a half years through much adversity.
It is a privilege to present insights from my experience as PMO lead in this remarkable programme team.” Join Chris Fisher from Nonsuch as he shares personal insights into the award-winning New Zealand Traveller Declaration (NZTD) Programme, recognised as New Zealand PMO of the Year 2025 (and New Zealand Technical Project of the Year 2025) Chris will reflect on his experience in the NZTD Programme that overcame complex national challenges to deliver a secure, user-centric digital border solution.
He’ll unpack how the PMO supported the evolving nature of the programme and tailored methodologies in a hybrid model, blending agile, traditional, and benefits-led approaches to enable rapid delivery, strong governance, and measurable impact.

events.id: Author Event: Wild Swimming in Aotearoa-13 Constable St, Newtown, Wellington 6021, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Author Event: Wild Swimming in Aotearoa
events.venue: 13 Constable St, Newtown, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Join us for this fabulous event featuring three wild-swimming writers, each inspired in their own unique way by their connection to the ocean. Authors Ingrid Horrocks, Shona Riddell, and Kate Camp will be in conversation with host and wild swimmer extraordinaire Corrina Connor.
Meet our panel:
Ingrid Horrocks is a writer whose work spans poetry, travel, environment, and community. Her many books include the memoir Where We Swim, described as “a book about family that travels by water in the body of a swimmer”, Women Wanderers, as well as two collections of poetry. Her new collection of short stories All Her Lives was published by Te Herenga Waka University Press in October.
Shona Riddell is an author, journalist, podcaster, and swimmer. Her books include Trial of Strength: Adventures and Misadventures on the Wild and Remote Subantarctic Islands and Guiding Lights: The Extraordinary Lives of Lighthouse Women, both published by Exisle Publishing. She has a Master's degree (Science in Society) and hosts a podcast called Swim Chats where she interviews swimmers, coaches, and marine scientists. Shona says: “I like cold weather, being near the ocean (and swimming in it), and learning about remote locations”.
Kate Camp is an award-winning poet and writer. Her first collection of poetry, Unfamiliar Legends of the Stars, won the NZSA Jessie Mackay Award for Best First Book of Poetry at the 1999 Montana New Zealand Book Awards, and she has gone on to publish six more poetry collections, most recently the wonderful Makeshift Seasons (2025). Kate is also a reviewer and essayist and is a familiar voice on Radio NZ.
Meet our host:
Corrina Connor is a marathon swimmer, cellist and one of our very own librarians. Be it the beaches or pools, libraries or music, Corrina makes the most of the opportunities Pōneke provides, in both work and play. In the past few years she has taken on several marathon swims, including Te Moana-o-Raukawa (Cook Strait), Te Ara-a-Kiwa (Foveaux Strait), and Lake Taupō (a mere 40.2 kilometres); as well as undertaking several hypothermia-inducing ‘ice swims’, defined as swimming in water of five degrees or less.
This is a free event -- all welcome. Please note: we expect this event to be extremely popular, and seating will be on a first come first served basis.
events.description:
Authors Ingrid Horrocks, Shona Riddell, and Kate Camp will be in conversation with host and wild swimmer extraordinaire Corrina Connor.
Her many books include the memoir Where We Swim, described as “a book about family that travels by water in the body of a swimmer”, Women Wanderers, as well as two collections of poetry.
Kate Camp is an award-winning poet and writer.
Her first collection of poetry, Unfamiliar Legends of the Stars, won the NZSA Jessie Mackay Award for Best First Book of Poetry at the 1999 Montana New Zealand Book Awards, and she has gone on to publish six more poetry collections, most recently the wonderful Makeshift Seasons (2025).
This is a free event -- all welcome.

events.id: Everybody Eats x Cliftons: Dinner in the Sky-Level 28/100 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Everybody Eats x Cliftons: Dinner in the Sky
events.venue: Level 28/100 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Dinner in the Sky: Celebrating Five Years of Impact
Join us for a spectacular one-night-only celebration as Everybody Eats marks five years of community impact in Wellington — hosted high above the city at Cliftons Wellington.
This special fundraising event brings together the partners, supporters, and champions who have helped transform rescued food into thousands of delicious meals served with dignity. With every plate, you’ve made Aotearoa a more connected, more nourished place — and now it’s time to celebrate the journey we’ve shared and the future we’re building together.
Suspended above Wellington’s breathtaking skyline, guests will indulge in a three-course menu while taking in sweeping views across our beautiful city. We can’t wait to raise a glass with you to five years of impact, the people who made it possible, and the exciting heights still to come.
What’s Included
• A three-course elevated dining experience with breathtaking views above the city
• A selection of wine is included with your meal, optional additional beverages available to purchase from the bar
• Entry to our Wonderful Weekend Experience raffle, with tickets from $20
• Special guests yet to be announced

events.id: Laureates line up: A poetry reading-Te Ahumairangi Ground Floor, National Library, cnr Molesworth & Aitken Streets, Thorndon, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Laureates line up: A poetry reading
events.venue: Te Ahumairangi Ground Floor, National Library, cnr Molesworth & Aitken Streets, Thorndon, Wellington
events.long_description:
Come along to ‘Laureates line up’, a poetry reading event featuring nearly all living New Zealand Poets Laureate.

It’s been almost 30 years since John Buck created the Te Mata Estate Winery Laureate Award and Bill Manhire became our first Laureate. Both will be there to support an outstanding line-up of poets: Elizabeth Smither, Jenny Bornholdt, Michele Leggott, Cilla McQueen, Ian Wedde, Karl Stead, Selina Tusitala Marsh, David Eggleton, Chris Tse, and Robert Sullivan.

Fergus Barrowman, publisher at Te Herenga Waka Victoria University Press, will MC the event. There will also be special readings to honour the late Vincent O’Sullivan and Brian Turner, shared by Vincent’s son Dominic and Brian’s partner, writer Jillian Sullivan.

This free event promises to be a highlight of Wellington’s poetry scene in 2025.

NZIER and Unity Books are providing the Prime Minister and all New Zealanders with summer reading options. This year's panel has chosen a diverse selection of books that present various perspectives, innovative ideas, and tackle contemporary issues facing New Zealand.

events.id: Sushi Unfolded: A Vegan Demonstration & Tasting-Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Sushi Unfolded: A Vegan Demonstration & Tasting
events.venue: Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington
events.long_description:
Back by popular demand! An evening of flavour, creativity, and connection as Balarama once again shares the craft of vegan sushi-making. From delicate hand-pressed pieces to beautifully rolled varieties, you’ll watch each step come to life in an engaging demonstration that’s both practical and inspiring.

Balarama’s grounded and approachable style makes the process easy to follow—even if it’s your first time exploring sushi-making. There’ll be space for questions throughout, and plenty of tastings along the way—so come hungry!

On the menu for the demo:

* Hand-pressed sushi (Nigiri)

* Sushi rolls (Maki-zushi)

* Tofu pocket sushi (Inari-zushi)

Afterwards, stay on for a full vegan dinner and dessert, freshly served and enjoyed in good company—a deliciously relaxed way to spend your evening.

Meet Balarama, your chef & host
Say hello to Balarama, our amazing chef who’s always meditating on his next culinary creation. At Bhakti Lounge, he’s known for mastering a range of cuisines—from comforting classics to vibrant international dishes. Lately, he’s been exploring the delicate and artful world of Japanese cooking, crafting plant-based sushi that’s as beautiful as it is flavorful. Balarama’s goal is to make food that feels nourishing, thoughtful, and easy to enjoy—like a home-cooked meal made with heart. With his calm, down-to-earth style, he makes even the most intricate dishes feel approachable.

events.id: Yoga Nidra: A Garden of Calm-Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Yoga Nidra: A Garden of Calm
events.venue: Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington
events.long_description:
An evening of deep rest and gentle renewal — followed by a nourishing plant-based dinner.

This guided Yoga Nidra session invites you to slow down and settle the body, mind, and breath. Through grounding awareness practices and serene visualizations, you’ll be guided into a state of profound rest, where the nervous system can unwind and reset.

The practice will follow a garden theme, inviting you to visualize planting seeds of peace, health, and intention. As you rest, these seeds can be gently nurtured — offering space for inner growth and the possibility of flourishing in your own time.

The space will reflect this theme with soft greenery, natural scents, and a soundscape inspired by the outdoors — all designed to evoke stillness and ease. Comforts are provided — mats and blankets — though you’re welcome to bring anything personal that helps you feel completely relaxed.

Whether you’re feeling depleted, overstimulated, or simply in need of a pause, this is an opportunity to tend to your inner garden and replenish from within.

After the session, enjoy a wholesome plant-based dinner and dessert, included in your ticket — a grounding way to connect, nourish, and carry the calm into your evening.

Meet Karuna, your host
Trained as a primary school teacher, she also has a background in psychology and Spanish. But her heart is in connecting with others, and she always brings a lively and warm energy to the space.

events.id: The "Other" Curriculum Roadshow - WELLINGTON-581 Evans Bay Parade, Kilbirnie, Wellington 6022, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: The "Other" Curriculum Roadshow - WELLINGTON
events.venue: 581 Evans Bay Parade, Kilbirnie, Wellington 6022, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Multiple Choice: Wellington Screening and Education Discussion
Join the Aotearoa Educators Collective (AEC) for a pivotal evening of discussion focused on the future of education with colleagues in Wellington. We are proud to host a screening of the compelling documentary, Multiple Choice - see the trailer here.
This film explores the profound and often challenging impacts of high-stakes, standardised testing on students, teachers, and the entire education system. Following the screening, we will open up a vital conversation about how we assess, Curriculum reform, and celebrating what is great about what we are doing now in Aotearoa New Zealand.
Your Voice Matters
This event is a crucial opportunity for educators, policymakers, parents, and community members to engage directly with key issues shaping our local schools and kura. We aim to:
Spark informed discussion about the role of assessment and qualifications.
Reflect on the implications for the ongoing redevelopment of the New Zealand Curriculum, national testing, and NCEA.
Encourage collaboration across our sector to reimagine equitable, future-focused pathways for all learners.
The Event Plan
Come together for a social networking event and evening of insight, hosted at St Patrick’s College.
The event will include:
A screening of the documentary Multiple Choice (approx. 1 hour).
A dynamic DRAFT Panel Discussion featuring a mix of local and national leaders:
Panel Convenor - Mark Potter | Principal of Berhampore School
Ragne Maxwell | Principal of Porirua College
Lynda Knight | Principal of Glenview Primary School
An Audience Q&A to foster broad community dialogue.
This is your chance to connect with peers and contribute your perspective to the national conversation. Secure your spot today!

events.id: Early Midnight Circus - An absurd late-night talk and comedy game-show-17b Allen Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Early Midnight Circus - An absurd late-night talk and comedy game-show
events.venue: 17b Allen Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Cue the house band, fire up the applause sign and prepare for an unhinged night of late-night comedy.
This November, Early Midnight Circus returns, hosted by the irrepressible Aaron James Douglas and it's more unhinged than ever. The stage is set: Keegan Thomas is your mischievous sidekick, Matt Hutton is back on keys as band leader, and the spotlight is on this month's guests – Mo Munn, Mog Connolly, and Q Potts… who have absolutely no idea what they’re walking into.
This isn’t your standard talk show: it’s a meticulously crafted disaster, designed to push guests into the deep end with absurd character comedy, unpredictable improv and sketch chaos that thrashes through any idea of “normal.” Early Midnight Circus is a "humorous hurricane where everything can (and will) go wrong," so prepare for a night of wild interviews, absurd surprises, audience-ambushing segments, musical mayhem and a crew determined to derail everything.
It’s a late-night gateway to one of the most absurd, experimental and ambitious shows of the year - with live music, sketch chaos and improvised mayhem in a format that’s part cabaret, part meltdown and all circus.
FEATURING: Aristarkh Tikhonov, Elliott Lam, Felix Uallach, Joel Luscombe, Keegan Thomas, Kipling DC, Lydia Sainsbury, Malcolm Morrison, Matt Hutton, Ralph Hilaga, Summer Begalka and Aaron James Douglas.

................

Some guidelines for a delightful experience:
-
Our events are GRATIS, we will not charge you anything but You are asked to order a drink directly upon arrival to participate
(Mandatory).
-
Outside food and drinks are not allowed.
-
Please respect the venues staff and make sure to leave the place clean and tidy before you leave.
-
Be polite and respectful.
Please kindly note that venue staff or our organizers will ban you from our events and community without any warning if you don't respect it. We offer you opportunities to make friends and improve your language skills for free. Be nice enough to make things easy for us.
................
How it's working:
We are working with a mingle setup and we usually don't have designated language tables or areas.
English and the local language are typically spoken.
If you would like to speak other languages, please ask the organizers or seek participants who meet your language expectations.
................
Things to keep in mind before joining:
-
By attending our events, you consent to being photographed or filmed. Photos and videos taken during the events will be shared on our social media. If you do not wish to appear in the photos, please send us a private message as soon as possible on Instagram (@blablalanguage).
-
Remember to keep an eye on your belongings and prioritize your own well-being. We are not responsible for any lost items or personal issues.
................
/

These gatherings are brought to you by BlaBla Language Exchange, spanning over 150 cities across 5 continents. We are always looking for new organizers. More information and application here: https://www.blablalanguageexchange.com/event-organizers

/

Whether you're a pro or a passionate newbie, we want YOU!
No cash, but lots of laughs and fame (well, sort of). We'll even give you a virtual high-five!

events.id: Ato To Ghana Fundraising Gig-The Rogue & Vagabond-Rogue & Vagabond
events.name: Ato To Ghana Fundraising Gig
events.venue: The Rogue & Vagabond
events.long_description:
AKWAABA!

Please come and support Ato on his journey getting back to Ghana!

Ato Kwamena is a composer and a percussionist from the Cape Coast in Ghana.
Inspired by West African highlife music, he has performed with numerous Aotearoa groups, including Culture Embassy, Orchestra of Spheres, ISKRA and Lord Echo.

Ato's mum recently passed away and we're fundraising money for a flight back home, so he can be with his family.

RAS JUDAH AND THE CULTURE EMBASSY

a 10-piece NZ band of varying cultural backgrounds, hence the name.
The cultural diversity of the band is reflected in the sound of the music
a fusion of African styles, Reggae/Ska, Jazz and Afro-Latin rhythms.

We describe our sound as Afrocentric-World Music as much of what we play is based on African rhythms and songs, which is where our lead-singer ‘Ras Judah’ and two of our master drummers come from (Botswana, Ghana and Tanzania respectively), plus Roots Reggae. Though everyone contributes their own culturally inspired sound, with other band members from Cuba, England and Japan, and others with Greek, Kiwiana and jazz backgrounds. Not just a musical treat representing many parts of the world, but also a visual one; a carnival of ethnic diversity and collaboration on stage!

ISKRA

Iskra are an otherworldly quartet heralding from Te Whanganui-a-Tara formed by saxophonist Josh Buckler and featuring Simon Grove (Niko Ne Zna) on helicon, Ato Kwamena (Culture Embassy) on percussion and David McGurk (Planet Hunter) on drums.

Inspired by the likes of Sons of Kemet and the London jazz scene, they bring driving grooves, soaring melodies and the fire of afro-beat, Balkan music and a style that is best described as brass-house. Think dance party at the end of the world, when the last lights have gone out

Discover Christmas Festive Fun & Craft Market 2025
Please join us for Discover Christmas- a fun, festive community event Friday 28th November 5-8:30pm at Discovery School. Gold coin entry.

There will be an indoor craft market offering a great opportunity for some Christmas shopping with the emphasis on local, eco-friendly and handmade products.

30+ stalls selling jewellery, art, healthy & beauty, cards, sweet treats, Christmas decorations, apparel, baby & kid goods and much more! Our students have been inspired and we will also be having some kid stalls featuring our amazing students.

events.id: James Nokise: One Night Rant | Wellington-The Fringe Bar,28 Allen Street, Te Aro, Wellington, New Zealand-All Events In
events.name: James Nokise: One Night Rant | Wellington
events.venue: The Fringe Bar,28 Allen Street, Te Aro, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
James Nokise: One Night Rant | Wellington
Irreverent, incorrigible, and just ever so outraged, award-winning comedian James Nokise lets loose in Wellington for one night only!

Politicians, policies, preachers, and protests are all in the line of fire as Nokise brings his fast paced, semi-chaotic, always cathartic, blend of humour and hot takes back to NZ for a hilarious hour of big laughs and the occasional frustrated scream.

One Night Rant is political comedy at its sharpest. From parliament scandals to global chaos, Nokise rips into the news cycle, mixing big laughs with bite-sized truths. This is a one-hour comedy special designed for anyone who’s ever shouted at the TV, despaired at the headlines, or secretly enjoyed watching politicians squirm.


About James Nokise

A multi-talented comedian, playwright, columnist, podcaster, theatre maker, and social commentator, James Nokise is known for his fearless approach and his ability to give a voice to underrepresented issues.

Over the course of his illustrious career James has been nominated twice for the Billy T Award (2005, 2006) and the Fred Award for Best New Zealand Show (2013), which he subsequently took out in 2019 for his show God Damn Fancy Man. He won Best Male Comedian at the NZ Comedy Guild Awards (2013), Spirit of the Festival at the 2021 NZ Comedy Fest and the Topp Prize (2024). James was also the winner of best documentary at the 2025 NZ radio awards for his series The Last Voyage of the Rainbow Warrior, and winner of the Best International Podcast at the 2025 Asia Podcast Awards.

James has an extensive touring career, including over a decade of shows in the NZ International Comedy Festival and multiple Comedy Gala performances, as well as years on the international Fringe Festival circuit, performing successful seasons in Edinburgh, Perth, and New York.

events.long_description:
JOURNEY TO SERENITY Yin Yoga and Sound Healing Special Series #1
Welcome to the Journey to Serenity Yin Yoga and Sound Healing twice monthly session starting on November 28th!!!

These beautiful, nourishing Yin and Sound Sessions are on the second and Fourth Friday of each month (between November 28th and March 28th 2026) and are held in the Meeting / Supper Room of the Paraparaumu Memorial Hall on Tutanekai Street.

It would be lovely to share this healing, nourishing restorative practice in the special energy and support you to give your life a boost of wellbeing and good feeling!!

INTRODUCING - SPECIAL WELCOME OFFER - TWO PEOPLE FOR $90 (You don't have to be a couple) - Book through bank transfer or message me directly

Unique Yin Yoga, Sound Healing, breathwork and meditation come together to create this specially guided, deeply relaxing and healing experience, held within a unique holistic framework that encourages reflection and self-care.

Take the time and space that this session offers, for yourself, and give yourself a gift of true nourishment.

Bryony Shanti from Heartsong Healing will use a wide range of special healing sound instruments along with her voice to guide you into peace, relaxation and stillness. The healing vibration of the specially chosen sounds will wash over you bringing deep clearing, balance and alignment. There is a experience of gratitude and blessing.

Bryony's sound works to strengthen and deepen the powerful work of Yin yoga teacher Bianca who will guide you through 90-minutes of restorative and uplifting poses that are intended for you relax, heal and to open more to receive the healing vibration of sound.

Bianca's Yin Yoga focuses on easily accessible and effective poses
which work into the deeper connective tissues of the body. These poses are held for anywhere between 90 seconds to 5 minutes to allow for an opening in the body, the perfect way to receive the sound vibrations.

Yin yoga invites us into stillness and gives space for both the mind and body to relax and release tension and stress.

OPEN TO ALL: Whether you have experience in either Yin Yoga and Sound Healing or are looking to try something completely new, you are very welcome to join in the journey into a sense of serenity. Beginners and experienced practitioners alike will find something nourishing for themselves in this session.

events.id: SAYA GRAY + Karen Nyame KG + MĀ-Meow Nui, 92 Vivian St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011,92 Vivian St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand, Wellington-All Events In
events.name: SAYA GRAY + Karen Nyame KG + MĀ
events.venue: Meow Nui, 92 Vivian St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011,92 Vivian St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand, Wellington
events.long_description:
SAYA GRAY + Karen Nyame KG + MĀ
Drunken Piano, Banished Music and The Others Way festival are hyped to announce a huge debut NZ appearance on Friday 28th November 2025 for Canada’s Saya Gray at Wellington’s stunning Meow Nui. Support comes from UK producer DJ Karen Nyame KG and Te Whanganui-a-Tara local artist Mā.

Taking the stage in Wellington ahead of her Others Way Festival appearance the next night, Saya Gray will be performing material from her excellent record released earlier this year SAYA.

Saya Gray has earned a reputation for electric, hypnotic live performances, leaping between instruments and genres, beguiling and entrancing her audiences.

“The alt-pop experimentalist delivered a mesmerizing, emotional performance with a triumphant sense of self” – Range Magazine

Watch her NPR Tiny Desk performance here.

Sharing the Meow Nui stage with Saya is UK DJ, producer, vocalist Karen Nyame KG.

“Channeling a deeply rooted attachment to the African diaspora, KG’s innovative and percussive assemblage of dance music spanned amapiano, afrobeats, uk funky, gqom and beyond.” – Resident Advisor

You can check our her boiler room set at Primavera here.

Rounding out the evening is local artist Mā. With their second album “Blame It On The Weather” being released earlier this year, Mā told RNZ “I’d rather talk about how we can move forward, how we can evolve, how we can work together better”.

Don’t miss this celebratory evening of creative expression and artistic genius. With Saya Gray and KG performing for the first time in New Zealand, tickets are on sale now from ticketek.co.nz

You may also like the following events from Banished Music:
Next month, 29th October, 09:30 am, C.W Stoneking - Auckland - The Tuning Fork in Auckland
Next month, 31st October, 09:30 am, C.W Stoneking - Pāuatahanui - The Morgans Clubhouse in Porirua
This November, 1st November, 09:30 am, C.W Stoneking - Dunedin - Hanover Hall in Dunedin
Also check out other Entertainment events in Wellington, Arts events in Wellington, Music events in Wellington.

events.long_description:
Catalytic Thinking for Capacity Builders
A 4 hour, practice-based session with Hildy Gottlieb.
Who this is for
People whose mahi is to help organisations do their best work: capacity builders,
advisors, funders and philanthropy staff, backbone and collective impact teams,
council and agency community advisors, sector peak bodies, governance support roles, coaches, consultants and trainers.
Why come
When you support others to thrive, the questions you ask can unlock entirely new
pathways. In this interactive session, you’ll learn practical, question-led approaches you can apply immediately in meetings, workshops, coaching and governance development.
Bring
A realworld situation you’re supporting (e.g., a governance challenge, a funding
conversation, a stuck collaborative). You’ll apply the tools to that context during the session.
Event details
Date: November 28, 2025
Time: 10am to 2pm
Location: 50 The Terrace, Wellington
Cost: $250+gst
Capacity: Limited to 30 participants
Accessibility: We aim to make this session accessible. Please let us know
any requirements (e.g., captions, stepfree access, dietary needs).

Presented by LEAD

events.name: Little Blast Trio with Oscar Laven
events.venue: Pyramid Club,272 Taranaki Street, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Little Blast Trio with Oscar Laven
Little Blast Trio (with special guest, Oscar Laven), play the music of ‘Triplicate’ - the 1988 album released by the Dave Holland trio on the legendary ECM label.

“Holy shit! You can do that in jazz?” thought these young players upon encountering it almost 30 years ago. Sure can! It’s time to put this lovely mix of tunes through their paces, refracted through the prism of these four stalwarts of the craft who have performed extensively in Aotearoa and beyond over the last few decades. Should be quite a gig.

Little Blast Trio is:
- Blair Latham ~ Tenor Sax/Bass Clarinet
- Alistair Isdale ~ Acoustic Bass
- Darren Mathieson ~ Drum kit
- with Oscar Laven ~ Tenor Sax/Bassoon

$15 presale tickets via UTR
$20 door sales ($10 unwaged)

Special thanks to CNZ for supporting Pyramid Club's programme

events.long_description:
Roots Rising Tour Palmerston North – House of Shem, Son and Water, Brutha Rodz
Roots Rising Tour – Presented by Titan Entertainment

Get ready for the Roots Rising Tour, hitting Aotearoa across four locations!

This is a tour you don’t want to miss, featuring Aotearoa reggae heavyweights — House of Shem, Son and Water, and Brutha Rodz — bringing energy and authentic roots music to the stage.

House of Shem are back and will perform all their classic hits alongside brand new music.

Joining them is Son and Water, led by the legendary Jamie Ferguson — the saxophonist and songwriter behind many of Katchafire’s biggest hits. Now performing alongside his sons, Jamie and the band are creating fresh, inspiring sounds that are capturing hearts all over Aotearoa.

Adding to the lineup is Brutha Rodz, a true roots reggae storyteller known for his smooth vocals, conscious lyrics, and powerful live performances that connect deeply with the crowd.

This will be the first time Son and Water perform in many of these cities, making it an extra special experience for fans of real Aotearoa roots reggae.

Tickets on sale now.

⸻


Tour Dates

📍 15 Nov – Hamilton – The Factory

📍 28 Nov – Palmerston North – The Royal

📍 29 Nov – Whakatāne – The Boiler Room

📍 6 Dec – Rotorua – Phoenix Bar

events.long_description:
We would love you to join us for our exclusive Déjeuner de Noël event, Bubbles & Canapé's with Lisa O'Neill being held at Quarter Acre, for our end of year Women in Business Networking Event.
The event is being held on Friday 28th of November, from 12.30-2.30pm. 
For over two decades, Lisa O'Neill has been electrifying audiences with her unique ability to deliver profound messages through side-splitting humour. After watching countless people struggle with energy, leadership and personal growth, Lisa discovered that transformation happens when hard truths are delivered with lightness and laughter. She's authored seven books, spoken to audiences of 5000+, and works with major organisations like Ray White, Foodstuffs and L'Oreal.
With infectious energy and practical wisdom, Lisa helps people get out of their own way to create magnificent lives and exceptional results.
What sets Lisa apart is her ability to make transformation feel both possible and fun. She's been called a "human Berocca" for her energising presence, and "emotionally nutritious" for her ability to nourish both hearts and minds. Through her speaking, books, and programs, Lisa empowers people to stop making excuses and start living magnificent lives. Her message is simple but profound: with the right energy, belief and action, you can have, be and do everything you want.
Join us Quarter Acre Private Event Venue - Don't miss the opportunity to hear from Lisa in person.
Friday 28th November
12.30-2.30pm  
Limited tickets - book today! 
Welcoming glass of bubbles and 2 course canapés
$60pp + bf

events.long_description:
How can we change or maintain people’s behaviour through marketing, and truly benefit the communities we serve?
This hands-on workshop will demonstrate how you can create behaviour change through social marketing. You’ll learn the basics of behaviour change marketing and communications, including best practice approaches to achieve behaviour change for social good outcomes.
Learn tools, tips, and strategies to help you:
·      Develop programmes or services that influence the communities you serve
·      Target resources effectively and choose tactics that have impact
·      Create communications and marketing campaigns that resonate
We are thrilled to have communications expert and social entrepreneur Tracey Bridges lead this workshop. She is a co-founder and director of The Good Registry, a social enterprise that directs consumer spending on gifts towards good causes. Tracey has significant governance experience in the not-for-profit space, including Whānau Āwhina Plunket and the WELLfed Charitable Trust, and is a fellow Public Relations Institute of New Zealand.
Tracey's insights are drawn from international and local practice, and a long career in behaviour change in social marketing, working on projects, including It’s Not OK, Sorted, Like Minds, Like Mine and many more.
Workshop presenter: Tracey Bridges
For out of towners or those who can’t make it on the day, this workshop will be recorded and shared on our website after the event, along with our other resources.
This is a free Community Comms Collective workshop for not-for-profits and collective volunteers hosted by Volunteer Wellington and supported by JacksonStone & Partners. We are grateful for their support and for our speaker for giving their time and talent pro bono.
Koha welcome to help cover venue hire.
St John’s in the City conference room is wheelchair accessible – please contact the Church Office with any queries https://www.stjohnsinthecity.org.nz/contact-us

events.long_description:
Join us for a relaxing and fun introduction to the world of handmade cards! Perfect way to create personalised cards to add a heartfelt touch to your gifts this festive season.
In this 2 hours workshop, you'll learn the fundamentals of creative card design, from selecting the right materials to mastering basic card-making techniques.
We'll cover everything you need to get started, including folding cardstock, layering paper and adding unique embellishments.
You'll leave with several handcrafted cards and the confidence to keep creating at home. All materials and tools are provided—just bring your creativity!
Participants can expect to make three cards during the session.
All necessary supplies including cardstock, punching machines and embellishments will be provided.
Techniques including flower making, quilling layering and embellishing will be taught including skills like - conceptualising, layout and playing with scale.

Saturday 29 November at 4 pm
materials provided
